repnme.cdata!: Kenya - Financial Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Adjustment Credit
            Project for Kenya was unsatisfactory. The project did not
            achieve its objectives, institutional development was only
            partially achieved, sustainability is unlikely, and the
            performance of the Bank was marginally satisfactory while
            the Borrower's was unsatisfactory. Several lessons can
            be learned from this project. First, the preconditions for
            an FSAO must be in place before successful changes in the
            pattern of credit allocation can be achieved. Second, unless
            disbursements of the foreign exchange lending accompanying
            FSAOs are closely controlled, they can offset or contradict
            the policy aims of the operations. Third, achieving
            market-determined interest rates requires that the
            Government operate in at least one truly competitive
            financial market, be it the market for bonds or foreign
            currency. Finally, the goal of bank restructuring exercises
            is to change Bank lending behavior not to make the balance
            sheets of troubled banks look like those of untroubled banks.

repnme.cdata!: Kenya - Financial Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Financial Sector
            Adjustment Credit Project for Kenya was unsatisfactory. The
            project achieved some of its objectives, institutional
            development was modest, sustainability is uncertain, and the
            performance of both the Bank and Borrower was marginally
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, reform is a technical as well as political
            process. Second, up-front actions required from the
            Government before the release of the first tranche were few.
            This prevented IDA from gauging the political feasibility of
            some of the components of the reform program, such as bank
            restructuring. Finally, interest rate liberalization was
            implemented with success. However, whether its timing was
            appropriate is questionable.

docna.cdata!:
Kenya - Financial Sector Adjustment Credit :
            Credit 2049 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Kenya - Financial Sector
            Adjustment Credit : Credit 2049 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

repnme.cdata!: Kenya - Financial Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The credit will support wide ranging
            policy and institutional reforms in the financial sector.
            The policy reforms include interest rate liberalization,
            more active use of generalized monetary policy instruments
            and reductions in the fiscal deficit. It also includes the
            revision of banking legislation, improved prudential
            supervision of the banking industry and a strengthening of
            the regulatory and incentive framework for capital markets
            development. The institutional reforms include the
            restructuring of troubled banks and "near bank"
            financial institutions as well as a strengthening of the
            Central Bank's capacity to supervise despository
            institutions. The institutional restructuring component will
            aid in recapitalizing financial institutions and
            compensating insured depositors and will be released only as
            action programs are agreed with IDA and implemented by the
            Deposit Protection Fund. The funds from the credit will
            finance general imports based on a negative list.
